I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on proposed loans 
to the Republic of Palau for the Water Sector Improvement Program.1 The program will support 
reform  of  the  water  and  sanitation  sector,  with  a  focus  on  improving  policy  and  legal 
frameworks, financial sustainability, and capacity development. 
II.  THE PROGRAM 
A.  Rationale 
2.  Low water tariffs and high water consumption. Water tariffs in Palau are low by 
international standards. Average household expenditure for water by the residents of Koror and 
Airai is about 1% of average monthly household income, compared with the international norm 
of 5%.2 Sanitation services in Palau are provided free of charge. The low water tariffs do not 
encourage  prudent  water  consumption  of  treated  water. 3   Consumption  is  estimated  at 
169 gallons per person a day, or more than 5 times greater than in Asian countries. 
3.  High subsidies. The water and sanitation sector is the only utility service in Palau that 
operates  with  high  subsidies.  Power  and  telecommunications  services  have  already  been 
corporatized and attract no government subsidies. Only 20% of the total operational cost of 
providing water and sanitation services is recovered through water charges, with the balance 
subsidized by the Government of Palau (government). The government’s budget support for the 
delivery of water and sanitation services for FY2010 of $2.4 million or 1.2% of gross domestic 
product (GDP) is similar to the government’s FY2010 projected fiscal deficit. Water subsidies 
are  not  targeted  to  the  poor  and  disproportionately  benefit  wealthier  Palauans.4 The 
government’s objective is to eliminate subsidies in the sector by increasing charges to reflect 
the full cost of supplying these services. This will help the government achieve its medium-term 
fiscal  target  of  a  5%  reduction  in  expenditure  over  the  next  5  years,  consistent  with  the 
International Monetary Fund’s recommendations.5 
4.  Water shortage may hinder tourism growth. Current demand projections show that 
without intervention, demand will exceed supply by 1.4 million gallons per day by 2020. Demand 
growth will be primarily driven by increasing tourist arrivals. Tourism is the largest private sector 
component of the economy, accounting for almost half of the country’s GDP. Tourist arrivals 
already exceed 80,000 per year, or four times the national population and are projected to grow 
by an average of 4.4% per annum over the next 10 years. The resident population of Koror and 
Airai is projected to grow by 0.5% per annum. Yields from water sources for the Koror–Airai 
water supply are insufficient to meet current demand during periods of prolonged drought, 
expected to intensify due to climate change. Improving the climate resilience of the water supply 
would require the construction of a large reservoir at an estimated cost exceeding $25 million, 
which  is  not  financially  viable.  However,  efficiency  improvements—including  demand-side 
management and reduction of nonrevenue water—are expected to remove the projected supply 
gap without adversely impacting tourism growth and associated private sector development. 
                                                 
1  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
2  About 14% of water provided in Koror and Airai is unmetered and incurs a flat fee. Metered connections are 
charged at $0.85 per 1,000 gallons. Water tariffs in the Pacific range from $0.19 to $7.50 per 1,000 gallons.  
3  Financial Analysis (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
4  These subsidies disproportionately benefit Palau’s wealthy, with 53% of all subsidized water delivered to those in 
the top income quartile. Government of Palau. 2008. Household Income and Expenditure Report. Koror. 
5  IMF. 2010. Article IV Staff Report. Washington, DC. The report recommends the government reduce expenditures 
by 1.5% of GDP each year, in part through the elimination of subsidies.

2 
5.  Fragmented responsibilities within the sector. The Koror–Airai water supply system 
provides treated water to approximately 77% of Palau’s population living in Koror and Airai 
states. The Koror–Airai water supply system is operated and maintained by the Bureau of Public 
Works  (BPW),  a  division  of  the  Ministry  of  Public  Infrastructure,  Industry  and  Commerce 
(MPIIC). BPW also operates and maintains separate systems in 14 states on behalf of the state 
governments.6  Multiple  agencies  are  responsible  for  water  supply  and  sewerage  service 
delivery, with no agreed plan or central coordination. The capital infrastructure project unit of 
MPIIC is responsible for the design and development of infrastructure. The BPW is responsible 
for water supply and sewerage treatment. The Ministry of Finance (MOF), Division of Utility 
Collections, is responsible for billing and payment collection. Currently, no agency is responsible 
for  tariff setting,  infrastructure  investment,  and  planning. No  budget is  provided  for  capital 
expenditure, as all public water infrastructure development since the Palau’s independence in 
1994 has been financed by grants. The water sector maintenance budget is approximately 1.7% 
of the value of the assets, which is below the international norm of 2%. Many of the assets have 
exceeded their design life, and thus have no book value. 
6.  Inefficient operations and management. Operations are inefficient and losses are 
high, with nonrevenue water at 43% of production. Collection rates have historically been poor, 
at 60%–65% of billing. Management and organizational planning is limited. Maintenance is 
under-funded, and not all needed technical skills are available. There is scope to improve 
performance  within  the  sector,  but  this  will  require  an  overhaul  of  current  operations  and 
management and the introduction of a capacity building program. Water and sewerage flow 
metering to improve maintenance and leak detection, adjustment of the pricing of water and 
sewerage, and remedial programs will also improve efficiency.  
7.  Inadequate  legal  and  regulatory  framework.  Current  legislation  is  outdated  and 
requires  updating  and  consolidation  to  empower  a  new  water  and  sewerage  authority, 
particularly in the areas of water abstraction and sewerage disposal, obligations for natural 
resource management, and rights of a utility to undertake its duties and functions as a water 
and sewerage services provider.  
8.  Legislative changes need to reflect the government’s commitment to reform in the water 
and sanitation sector, recognizing that tariff reform in the sector is critical to reduce demand and 
provide a reliable, full cost-recovery service (footnote 6). This commitment is articulated in the 
Medium-Term Development Strategy (MTDS) 2009–2014,7 which was developed to support 
implementation of the National Master Development Plan.8 The program supports the MTDS 
goals and actions by (i) investing in the water and sanitation sector, (ii) moving state-owned 
enterprises toward full cost recovery, and (iii) reducing government expenditure by eliminating 
subsidies. The Palau country partnership strategy, 2009–20139 supports the goals and actions 
of the government’s MTDS and includes technical and financial support for sewerage sector 
planning, improving water resource management, and water and sanitation sector infrastructure 
development. 
9.  The program also applies lessons from earlier ADB policy programs in the Pacific, as 
well as ADB's approach to engaging with weakly performing countries, notably by (i) adopting a 
country-led set of policy actions developed in an open, participatory manner and at a pace in

keeping with country practices; and (ii) initiating a long-term policy dialogue and providing 
targeted technical assistance (TA) support.10 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The  impact  of  the  program  will  be  sustainable  water  and  sewerage  services.  The 
program outcome will be that the demand for water and sewerage services is met. 
C.  Outputs 
 
1.   Legal and Policy Framework for Water Sector Improvement is in Place 
11.  The program will establish the policy and legal framework to enable the provision of 
sustainable and efficient water and sewerage services by an independent, government-owned 
corporate entity. The government is expected to pass an act that would create the Palau Water 
and Sewer Corporation (PWSC). The act will empower the PWSC, through an independent 
board, to provide water and sewerage services throughout Palau and set tariffs for full cost 
recovery.  The  draft  act  covers  (i)  the  transfer  of  physical  water  sector  assets  from  the 
government  to  PWSC,  (ii)  the  transfer  of  the  existing  staff  from  the  relevant  government 
ministries, and (iii) the right to collect and retain revenue and enter into debt. Regulations for 
detailed operational issues have been prepared. The board will set its own bylaws. The draft act 
also allows for outsourcing the management function to a private company of international 
standing. The PWSC will meet external water and sanitation quality standards.  
12.  Under the program, the government will increase the water tariffs in 2010 by regulation 
and establish a sewerage tariff for the first time. Further tariff increases will be required before 
the PWSC is fully operational, and the government has committed to making these increases in 
FY2012 under the program. 
13.  During  program  implementation,  the  government  will  issue  policies  for  public 
management of water resources (including a National Water Resources Management Plan) that 
incorporate the rights and responsibilities of water users in helping to manage the country’s 
water resources. The government will also seek changes to legislation to implement the plan 
and to further assist the sustainable management of Palau’s terrestrial and marine resources 
including: (i) permits for water abstraction, (ii) issuing abstraction permits, and (iii) sewage 
treatment and disposal.  
 
2.  An  Independent  Palau  Water  and  Sewer  Corporation  Delivers  Improved 
Services 
14.  Transition  to  Palau  Water  and  Sewer  Corporation.  To  improve  the  operational 
efficiency and reduce the fragmentation of responsibilities in the sector, the PWSC will be 
created. The PWSC will be legally established including the appointment of a board and the 
board’s appointment of key staff. Over the next 12-18 months, the necessary regulations, 
policies, and plans for the PWSC to be able to deliver water and sewerage services will be 
prepared.  These  will  include:  (i)  preparation  of  an  organizational  structure  to  deliver  the 
functions of the PWSC, (ii) finalization of an assets register, (iii) development of an asset 
management plan, (iv) preparations to transfer current staff from the government to the PWSC, 
                                                 
10 ADB. 2009. ADB Support for Public Sector Reforms in the Pacific: Enhance Results through Ownership, Capacity, 
and Continuity. Manila. ADB’s approach to fragile situations is outlined in ADB. 2007. Achieving Development 
Effectiveness in Weakly Performing Countries. Manila.

4 
(v) a human resource management plan, (vi) adoption of financial management arrangements 
and  systems,  and  (vii)  development  of  new  billing  and  collection  systems.  In  addition  to 
providing  support  for  organizational  and  management-related  strengthening,  there  will  be 
capacity building in technical management and planning, including through the development of 
(i) guidelines and technical standards, (ii) an infrastructure maintenance plan, (iii) an investment 
plan, and (iv) an institutional development plan. The program will provide ongoing technical 
support during this transition phase. 
15.  MPIIC will continue to deliver water and sewerage services while the PWSC is preparing 
to take full responsibility. When all preparations are complete, the President will declare the 
PWSC ‘operationally effective’ and the staff and relevant assets will transfer to the PWSC.   
16.  Capacity building. A capacity-building program to help improve the effectiveness and 
efficiency of services will be implemented in early 2011 through the program. The capacity 
development program will initially be implemented within MPIIC Water and Sewer Divisions, and 
will continue within PWSC when operations commence. Components of the capacity-building 
program  cover  (i)  mentoring  of  management  personnel,  (ii)  strengthening  administrative 
capacity, and (iii) developing the technical skills of the water and sewerage operation teams. 
The government will ensure PWSC is professionally managed and operated, and the draft 
PWSC act requires an experienced management team to be in place. 
17.  The program steering committee (PSC),11 MPIIC, and the program implementation unit 
(PIU) will manage and oversee the transitional activities. The PIU will contract external TA to 
help with the transition to, and capacity building of, the PWSC. This assistance will include 
expertise  in  utility  management,  operational  management,  and  finance.  Once  operational, 
PWSC will be responsible for delivering water and sewage services in Palau. The government 
will  continue  to  provide  budget  support  to  the  sector  until  the  PWSC  becomes  financially 
independent by FY2015. Tariffs will be progressively increased to achieve full cost recovery 
during this time.  
18.  ADB technical assistance. To further support the capacity development of the PWSC, 
ADB will utilize resources under an existing TA project to facilitate its transition to operational 
effectiveness.12 TA funds will help develop the maintenance, operations, and infrastructure 
investment plans.  
19.  Improving Palau Water and Sewer Corporation operational efficiency. Consistent 
with the MTDS’s overarching goal of reducing costs and ensuring water conservation, the 
government will set benchmarks for operational efficiency improvements. During transition to full 
cost recovery, PWSC will be expected to (i) reduce nonrevenue water from 43% to 25%, (ii) 
progressively  increase  tariffs  to  achieve  full  cost  recovery  by  FY2015,  and  (iii)  improve 
collections to at least 95% of billings by FY2015. The board will consider additional performance 
standards for the PWSC. 
20.  To achieve these benchmarks, the PWSC will have to improve the efficiency of water 
and  sewer  sector  operations,  including  by  (i)  implementing  100%  consumer  metering,  (ii) 
disconnecting all illegal connections, (iii) identifying non-metered connections and scheduling 
their  meter  connections,  (iv)  improving  water  management  through  better  monitoring  by 
installing flow meters within the existing network and at all storage tanks, and (v) reducing 
                                                 
11  The PSC is established and consists of the vice-president and minister of finance (chair) and representatives from 
MPIIC, the Office of the President, the Office of the Vice-President, the Palau Public Utility Corporation, a member 
of the House of Delegates, and a member of the Senate. 
12  ADB. 2009. Technical Assistance to Palau for Preparing the Sanitation Sector Development Project. Manila.

5 
system  losses  through  the  preparation  and  implementation  of  a  leak  detection  and  repair 
program.  Some  of  these  measures  will  take  until  FY2015  to  complete.  Meeting  these 
benchmarks will help achieve reliable and affordable services.  
  3.  Full Cost Recovery is Achieved in the Water and Sewerage Sector 
21.  The MTDS outlines the government’s policy of requiring people to pay tariffs that allow 
services and utilities to operate on a full cost-recovery basis. This will allow the government to 
remove  subsidies  and  enable  the  sector  to  self-invest  in  maintenance  and  infrastructure 
development.  Transition  to  full  cost  recovery  will  take  4 years.  The  program  supports  (i) 
progressive tariff increases up to the point of full cost recovery; and (ii) budget support to cover 
the difference between tariff revenue and actual costs during this transition. The first and 
second tariff increases will be regulated by the Minister of Finance in (i) late 2010, to become 
effective in February 2011; and (ii) in late 2011, to become effective in February 2012. The third 
and fourth tariff increases being recommended to achieve full cost recovery for PWSC will be 
enacted by the PWSC board in subsequent years.  
22.  To achieve full cost recovery in 4 years, tariffs for consumption of up to 5,000 gallons of 
water per month will need to increase from $0.85 to $1.30 per 1,000 gallons consumed (a 53% 
increase). Sewerage tariffs will also need to be charged, and will start at $0.30/1,000 gallons. 
Tariffs  for  high  residential  water  users  (over  5,000  gallons)  and  non-residential  users  will 
increase more steeply to $3.36/1,000 gallons. These rates will encourage prudent consumption 
and facilitate maintaining a sustainable supply of treated water. Commercial sewerage tariffs will 
be introduced at $1.70/1,000 gallons and increase steadily over the 4 years. 
23.  During the transition to full cost recovery, PWSC will operate at a loss. The government, 
through the program, has committed to fund the shortfall through annual budget appropriations 
totaling $5.1 million. This budget support will include $2.5 million in FY2011, $1.5 million in 
FY2012, with the remaining $1.1 million depending on the tariffs set by the PWSC board in late 
2012 and 2013. The government will enter into a financial agreement with the PWSC to (i) 
assist in implementing the sector reforms, (ii) make possible the improvements in technical and 
managerial capacity and operational efficiency, and (iii) promote water conservation and health 
awareness. The government will provide financial assistance in the form of a loan of up to 
$6 million to the PWSC to achieve these objectives. Through the financial agreement, the 
government will also provide grant transition financing of up to $2.6 million.13 The grant will 
cover the difference between revenue collected by the PWSC and the full cost of operations. 
24.  At the end of the transition to full cost recovery in October 2015, the government will no 
longer provide financial support to the sector. The PWSC will have the ability to charge tariffs to 
maintain infrastructure and make new investments. The government will have improved its fiscal 
position by at least $2.2 million (1.1% of GDP) per year as recommended by the International 
Monetary Fund (footnote 5). 
4.  Effective Public Consultation is in Place 
25.  ADB lessons from implementing reform across the Pacific stress the importance of 
public consultation before and during the reforms. Broad public support is important to achieving 
reform in the water and sanitation sector. Under the program, the government has undertaken a 
public  advocacy  program  with  politicians,  civil  society,  and  community  groups  on  the 
government’s policy, its importance to Palau’s future, and the impact on the people. In doing so, 
                                                 
13 The value of the grant will be determined by the date on which the PWSC is declared operationally effective. Until 
this time, budget support will be channeled through the MPIIC.

6 
they have sought support for the creation of PWSC and for tariff reform, thereby reducing the 
risk that support will wane over time. The PWSC will conduct an awareness campaign on the 
importance of water conservation and behavior change to help the community adapt to the new 
policy arrangements and minimize their impact. The awareness campaign will include support 
for sanitation, hygiene, water use, and health awareness. 
26.  Impacts  of  government  reform.  The  impact  on  the  water  sector’s  financial 
sustainability and operational performance will fundamentally improve under the reforms being 
introduced by the government. The PWSC will return a profit by FY2015 and the government’s 
fiscal position will be improved by at least $2.2 million per year (Table 1). The creation and 
strengthening of the PWSC will enable significant efficiency improvements and set the sector on 
a path to long-term sustainable management of the resources to facilitate growth and address 
the impacts of climate change in Palau.

D.  Program Costs and Financing 
27.  The government has requested (i) a loan of $12.6 million from ADB’s ordinary capital 
resources (OCR), and (ii) a loan in various currencies equivalent to SDR2.23 million ($3.4 
million equivalent) from ADB’s Special Funds resources (Asian Development Fund [ADF] loan) 
to help finance its reform program. The OCR loan will have a 15-year term, including a grace 
period  of  3  years,  an  annual  interest  rate  determined  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  London 
interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility, a commitment charge of 0.15% per year, 
and such other terms and conditions as set forth in the draft loan agreement. The government 
has provided ADB with (i) the reasons for its decision to borrow under ADB’s LIBOR-based 
lending facility based on these terms and conditions, and (ii) an undertaking that these choices 
were its own independent decision and not made in reliance on any communication or advice 
from ADB. The ADF loan will have a 24-year term, including a grace period of 8 years, an 
interest rate of 1.0% per annum during the grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter, and 
such other terms and conditions set forth in the draft loan agreement. The borrower will be the 
Republic of Palau. Proceeds of the program loan are expected to be used within 24 months 
from the date of loan effectiveness. 
28.  The  size  of  the  Program  has  been  determined  after  due  consideration  of:  (i)  the 
projected financing requirements for the sector over the implementation period at about $16 
million; (ii) the lack of  available cofinancing resources; (iii) the direct costs of supporting tariff 
reform, Output 3, of approximately $5.1 million; (iv) adjustment costs in restructuring the sector, 
including  reticulation  network  refurbishment,  improving  sector  commercial  capacity,  and 
capacity development programs through Outputs 1, 2, and 4 of approximately $6 million; and (v)

7 
the significance and sensitivity of the policy actions. The government will contribute $1.2 million 
through in-kind and cash contributions to implement the program. 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
29.  Program management. MOF will be the executing agency and will be responsible for 
the overall implementation, financial management, and budget support required under the 
program. The implementing agency will initially be MPIIC, with PWSC serving as implementing 
agency once it becomes operationally effective (prior to the release of the second tranche). The 
implementing agency will be responsible for implementation of outputs 2, 3, and 4 under the 
direction of the PSC. A financing agreement between the government and the PWSC will 
manage the rights and obligations of the PWSC to implement the program. MOF will establish 
the PIU and provide ongoing support to the executing agency and implementing agencies. The 
PIU will be staffed with national staff supported by international consultants. The PSC will be 
responsible for overall direction, guidance, and monitoring of the program. The government and 
PSC recognize the challenges and have engaged all the stakeholders early in the reform 
process. The government and members of the PSC were involved in establishing Palau’s power 
utility and bring this experience and insight to the program. Implementation arrangements are in

full foreign exchange costs, excluding local taxes and duties, of items produced and procured in 
ADB member countries and exclude items on the list of ineligible items and imports financed by 
other bilateral and multilateral sources.16 No supporting import documentation will be required if, 
during each year that loan proceeds are expected to be disbursed, the value of Palau’s total 
imports minus imports from nonmember countries, ineligible imports, and disbursements made 
under other official development assistance is greater than the amount of the loan expected to 
be disbursed during such year. The government will certify its compliance with this formula with 
each withdrawal request. Otherwise, import documentation under existing procedures will be 
required. ADB reserves the right to audit the use of the loan proceeds and verify the accuracy of 
the government's certification. 
34.  Accounting, auditing, and performance management. The government will maintain 
records of account for the program. Prior to withdrawal, the government will open a deposit 
account  at  a  bank  acceptable  to  ADB  to  receive  the  loan  proceeds.  The  account  will  be 
managed, operated, and liquidated in accordance with terms satisfactory to ADB. MOF, PSC, 
and ADB will monitor the progress of the program and measure performance.   
III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
A.   Economic and Financial 
35.  The  government  has  made  progress  in  improving  public  financial  management, 
particularly in government financial accounting and reporting. The public finance legislative 
framework  is  robust  and  financial  management  systems  are  good.  Expenditure  has  been 
aligned with revenue in the current fiscal year. However, systems for budget preparation and 
management still require improvement. Budget appropriations are not aligned with revenue, 
leading to persistent deficits. Cash management planning also inhibits the ability to plan and 
manage expenditure. The Office of the Public Auditor and Office of the Special Prosecutor 
perform  their  mandate  effectively.17  Recognizing  these  financial  management  issues,  the 
government sought ADB’s assistance to strengthen budget preparation and management.18 
Linked with this work, the Pacific Financial Technical Assistance Centre is working with MOF to 
strengthen cash management. 
36.  Palau’s government debt is low at 9.6% of GDP. The impact of the program loan will be 
to increase government debt to 15.5% of GDP. Government debt servicing, currently 0.8% of 
GDP will also remain low. 
                                                 
15 ADB. 1998. Simplified Disbursement Procedures and Related Requirements for Program Loans. Manila. 
16  List of Ineligible Items (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
17 ADB conducted a governance assessment of Palau using the Governance and Anticorruption Action Plan I 
methodology in preparation for the Palau Country Partnership Strategy, 2009–2013.  
18 ADB. 2009. Technical Assistance to the Republic of Palau for Implementing a Medium-Term Budget Framework. 
Manila (TA 7421-PAL).

9 
B.  Governance 
37.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with  the  government  and  MOF.  Consistent  with  its  commitment  to  good  governance, 
accountability, and transparency, ADB reserves the right to investigate, directly or through its 
agents, any alleged corrupt, fraudulent, collusive, or coercive practices relating to the program. 
To support these efforts, relevant provisions of ADB’s Anticorruption Policy are included in the 
loan documents.19  
38.  MPIIC has the technical skills to maintain the water and sanitation systems, but lacks 
specialist  managers,  planners,  and  engineers  needed  to  create  a  separate  entity  outside 
government. Despite strong champions for this reform, there is also a limited cadre of people 
capable of managing the organizational change required by the program. The government 
recognizes the need for technical support and managers of organizational change. They will use 
loan funds for this purpose.  
39.  The National Government Procurement Law is applied to all expenditure of government 
funds.  It  emphasizes  the  government's  policy  of  promoting  fair  and  competitive  public 
procurement and prescribes most of the important procurement matters to be followed. The law 
is enforced strictly. Competition and efficiency is maintained in MPIIC’s procurement. 
C.  Poverty and Social 
40.  The PWSC’s transition to full cost recovery in 4 years is designed to minimize the impact 
on the poor. The new tariff structure will better target the needs of the poor. The first 5,000 
gallons  (double  the  World  Health  Organization’s  recommendations)  is  below  the  cost  of 
production to ensure affordability to the poor. The average total household water and sewerage 
bill will increase from 1% to 1.9% of average household income progressively over the 4 years. 
The  program  includes  the  promotion  of  water  conservation  and  health  awareness  at  the 
household level. The reliability of water supply during drought will improve, benefiting the poor. 
The program will improve the climate resilience of Palau’s water resources. Over time, the 
program will yield broadly distributed social benefits by providing a foundation for improving the 
fiscal position of Palau. This will enhance the sustainable delivery of essential services.20 
D.  Safeguards  
41.  The  program  has  been  classified  under  category  C  for  environment,  involuntary 
resettlement,  and  indigenous  peoples.  Improved  national  water  resource  planning,  water 
conservation, and strengthening of environmental quality control regulations relating to water 
abstraction and sewerage outflow are expected to yield positive environmental outcomes and 
ameliorate the negative impacts of climate change in the future. 
E.  Risks and Mitigation Measures 
42.  Risk  will  be  monitored  and  managed  by  the  PIU  during  program  implementation. 
Changes in risk assessment and risk mitigation will be monitored by the government and ADB 
through its scheduled reviews. Major risks and mitigating measures are in Table 3.21

IV.   ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 
43.  The government and MOF have assured ADB that implementation of the program shall 
conform to all applicable ADB policies including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement, as described in detail 
in the program implementation arrangements and loan documents. 
44.  The loan will become effective after: (i) all conditions for the release of the first tranche of 
the program, as specified in the policy matrix and set out in Attachment 2 to Schedule 3 to the 
loan agreement, have been complied with to the satisfaction of ADB; and (ii) the government 
has established the PSC and the PIU for the program.  
V.   RECOMMENDATION 
45.  I am satisfied that the proposed loans would comply with the Articles of Agreement of 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve  
(i)  the  loan  of  $12,600,000  to  the  Republic  of  Palau  for  the  Water  Sector 
Improvement Program from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, with interest to be 
determined in accordance with ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-
based lending facility; for a term of 15 years, including a grace period of 3 years; 
and such other terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with 
those set forth in the draft loan agreement presented to the Board; and  
(ii)  the loan in various currencies equivalent to SDR2,230,000 to the Republic of 
Palau for the Water Sector Improvement Program from ADB’s Special Funds 
resources with an interest charge at the rate of 1.0% per annum during the grace 
period and 1.5% per annum thereafter; for a term of 24 years, including a grace 
period of 8 years; and such other terms and conditions as are substantially in 
accordance with those set forth in the draft program loan agreement presented to 
the Board.
